lines.text: You know, I think I'll get you to take me to San Francisco with you.
Oh? Why to San Francisco?
Well, isn't that the place where they found all the gold?
[laughs]
He's a good soldier when he knows what he's fighting for.
It's easy when it's something you can see; a wall, a hill, a river, but how can you explain to them when it's for a principle.
You can't. Not here in China, it's too far from home.
You have to admire Sir Arthur; he always manages to give the impression that God must be an Englishman.

[in the hospital, while the baroness refuses medical assistance]
Don't you want to live?
I *have* lived!

The boxer bandits will be dealt with, but the anger of the Chinese people cannot be quieted so easily. The Germans have seized Kiaochow, the Russians have seized Port Arthur, the French have obtained concessions in Yunnan, Kwan See and Kwantang. In all, 13 of the 18 provinces of China are under foreign control. Foreign warships occupy our harbours, foreign armies occupy our forts, foreign merchants administer our banks, foreign gods disturb the spirit of our ancestors. Is it surprising that our people are aroused?
Your Majesty if you permit me to observe, the violence of the Boxers will not redress the grievances of China.
China is a prostrate cow, the powers are not content milking her, but must also butcher her.
If China is a cow, Your Majesty, she is indeed a marvelous animal. She gives meat as well as milk, and yet grows stronger.

[Just before the Relief Force arrives]
Those guns! They aren't Chinese!

[Regarding the Boxers massed on the Tartar Wall]
No sign of activity, hmm?
No sir, I think they're all asleep.
Ah, but we'd better not be Sergeant.
[Nodding to sleeping soldiers]
You'd better wake them all up.

[to English Soldier]
Wake up!
[to German Soldier]
Guten Morgen!
[to French Soldier]
Bonjour! Bonjour!
[to Italian Soldier]
Buongiorno!
[Picks up and looks at hat of Japanese Marine]
... Good Morning?
Good Morning.

[Clapping sarcastically]
Congratulations, Sir Arthur! It seems the British have won another bloodless victory!
I take it you have now unanimously decided to stay.
I shall report in my diary the first vote was nine-to-one, and that in a... friendly spirit it was then decided to make the decision unanimous.

[Unannounced, entering her husband's study]
I'm sorry, Arthur. Are you busy?
Of course I am. I *always* am.
Busier than usual? Or just busy?
Both.
Do you remember what Napoleon said about China?
"Let China sleep. For when she awakens, the world will tremble."
He did say an awful lot, didn't he?

[Arguing with his sister about the family's pet dog, Ming]
Mother says we can't take Ming back to England with us.
I *won't* leave my dog!
He's *my* dog!

[indignant]
Who feeds him?
Who taught him to sit up? He's *mine*!
we'll cut him exactly in two, and you'll each get half.
Oh, father, don't play King Solomon.

[chuckles]
I tried...

Do you think that if a child dies in a foreign place without ever having seen home that its soul doesn't rest? I think it goes into limbo - an enormous, empty Chinese limbo. And it wanders there, lost and crying...
What should I tell you, Major?
Well, that you're happy I'm with you.
Are you always this direct?
I'm a Marine, ma'am. I don't have much time.
